Mackay, John Alexander, 1838-1923. (translator)
description: Oxenden, Ashton: 1808-1892. // Mackay, John Alexander: 1838-1923. Native of Moosonee, Ontario; trained under Bishop Horden; ordained in the Church of England, 1862; at York Factory, 1862-1864, Stanley, 1864-1876, Nepowewin and Carlton, 1876-1877, and Battleford, 1877-1879; Cree tutor at Emmanuel College, Prince Albert, 1880-1884; in charge of Indian reserves at Battleford, 1885-1887; professor of divinity at Emmanuel, 1887-1900; superintendent of missions in diocese of Saskatchewan, 1900-1921; reorganized day school at Little Pine reserve, 1922; translator of religious works into Cree (Hopkins, Canadian annual review, 1923). // Text in English and Cree syllabics; one line of Cree syllabics at head of title. Also published, London: Society for Promoting Christian Knowledge, 1909 and 1924 (185p.; 1000 copies each time); and as The pathway of safety: Translated by J.A. Mackay into the language of the Cree Indians of the Ecclesiastical Province of Rupert's land, North-West Canada, 1909: Re-written for the use of the Cree Indians in the Diocese of Moosonee by J.T. Griffin , London: Society for Promoting Christian Knowledge, 1932 ([2], 210p.). Syllabic characters in 1932 edition said to be all hand-drawn and then reproduced.
